definitions: having been turned around a central point or axis
moved or repositioned from an original orientation or angle
examples: The rotated image appeared upside down on screen
She examined the rotated sculpture from different angles
The rotated shifts gave everyone different working hours
His rotated position offered a better view

definitions: relating to or characterized by turning around an axis or center point
happening in a regular sequence where positions or duties alternate systematically
examples: The rotational motion of the earth creates day and night
The engine's rotational speed exceeded safe limits
They implemented a rotational schedule for weekend duties
The rotational presidency changes every six months

definitions: having undergone decomposition through bacterial or fungal action
having become morally degraded or corrupted over time
examples: The rotted wood crumbled at the slightest touch
They removed all the rotted fruit from storage
His rotted values poisoned the entire organization
The rotted system needed complete reform

definitions: suffering from decay; decomposed and foul-smelling
morally degenerate, dishonest, or corrupt in character
extremely unpleasant, disagreeable, or of very poor quality
examples: The rotten eggs produced a terrible smell
Don't eat that rotten apple
The rotten politician accepted bribes regularly
Their rotten scheme finally got exposed
She had a rotten day at work
What rotten weather we're having

definitions: having an uneven or irregular surface; not smooth or level
characterized by violence, force, or lack of gentleness
not exact or detailed; approximate or preliminary
difficult and unpleasant; characterized by hardship or discomfort
examples: The rough texture scratched her delicate skin
They drove carefully on the rough road
The rough seas made everyone seasick
His rough manner frightened the children
She gave a rough estimate of costs
This rough draft needs more work
They went through a rough patch in their marriage
It's been a rough week at work

definitions: having a circular or curved shape without angles or corners
complete in itself; constituting a full cycle or series
having a plump, full-figured shape; well-filled out
examples: The round table seated eight people comfortably
Earth appears round from space
They enjoyed a round of golf every Sunday
Let me buy this round of drinks
Her round face beamed with happiness
The baby had round chubby cheeks

definitions: following a longer, less direct route than necessary to reach a destination
not direct in speech or action; avoiding straightforward expression
examples: We took a roundabout route to avoid traffic
The roundabout journey added an hour
She gave a roundabout answer to avoid the truth
His roundabout way of speaking confused everyone

definitions: having curves rather than sharp angles or corners
fully developed in all aspects; complete and balanced
pronounced with lips pursed in a circular shape
examples: The rounded corners made the table safer for children
She preferred rounded shapes to angular ones
He received a rounded education in arts and sciences
The program offers rounded character development
The rounded vowels require specific lip positioning
French has many rounded vowel sounds

definitions: somewhat round in shape but not perfectly circular
examples: The roundish stone made a good paperweight
She drew a roundish circle freehand
His roundish face had soft, gentle features
The roundish fruit wasn't quite spherical

definitions: causing excitement, enthusiasm, or strong emotional response
causing someone to wake up or become alert and active
examples: The rousing speech motivated the entire team
They sang rousing patriotic songs
A rousing chorus of birdsong greeted the dawn
The rousing alarm forced him from bed

definitions: performed as part of a regular procedure or schedule
commonplace and predictable; lacking in excitement or interest
examples: She followed her routine morning exercises religiously
The routine maintenance kept equipment running smoothly
It was just another routine day at the office
The routine tasks became increasingly tedious

definitions: moving from place to place without a fixed destination or purpose
examples: The roving reporter covered stories worldwide
His roving eye scanned the crowded room
A roving band of musicians entertained the festival
She led a roving lifestyle for years

definitions: rough and disorderly in behavior; creating noise and disturbance
examples: The rowdy crowd had to be controlled by security
Their rowdy behavior got them ejected
The bar became rowdy after midnight
A rowdy group of teenagers disrupted the movie

definitions: relating to or belonging to a king, queen, or their family
suitable for royalty; magnificent, impressive, or first-rate
examples: The royal family attended the state dinner
She received a royal invitation to the palace
They gave us the royal treatment at the hotel
It was a royal mess to clean up

definitions: made from or consisting of elastic waterproof substance from tropical plants or synthetic materials
examples: She wore rubber gloves while washing dishes
The rubber tires provided good traction
A rubber stamp approved all the documents
The rubber ball bounced high

definitions: having the texture or consistency of rubber
tough and elastic in an unpleasant way, especially describing overcooked food
examples: The rubbery material stretched without breaking
His rubbery legs wobbled after the marathon
The overcooked eggs were disappointingly rubbery
The rubbery chicken was hard to chew

definitions: having the deep red color of a ruby gemstone
examples: Her ruby lips contrasted with pale skin
The wine had a beautiful ruby color
She wore a ruby dress to the gala
The sunset painted the sky ruby red

definitions: having a healthy reddish color, especially of the face
used as a mild intensifier or expression of annoyance in British English
examples: His ruddy cheeks showed he'd been outdoors
The farmer had a ruddy, weathered complexion
I can't find the ruddy keys anywhere
What a ruddy mess this turned into

definitions: offensively impolite or ill-mannered in behavior or speech
roughly made or done; lacking subtlety or sophistication
abrupt and unpleasant in effect; startlingly sudden
examples: His rude comments upset everyone at dinner
It's rude to interrupt when someone's speaking
They lived in rude shelters made of branches
The rude tools were effective but primitive
She received a rude awakening about the costs
The alarm was a rude shock to his system

definitions: involving or limited to basic principles; not fully developed
relating to an immature, undeveloped, or basic form
examples: She had only rudimentary knowledge of French
The tribe used rudimentary farming techniques
The rudimentary organs showed no function
His rudimentary understanding needed improvement

definitions: having a disturbed, uneven, or wrinkled surface or appearance
emotionally disturbed, annoyed, or made uncomfortable
examples: The ruffled water showed where fish had jumped
Her ruffled hair needed brushing
He remained calm despite her ruffled feelings
The criticism left him visibly ruffled

definitions: having a rough, uneven, or rocky surface, especially of landscape
strongly built and capable of withstanding rough handling
having strong, masculine features or a tough, determined character
examples: The rugged coastline attracted adventurous hikers
They crossed rugged mountain terrain
This rugged laptop survives extreme conditions
The rugged construction ensures durability
His rugged good looks appealed to many
Her rugged determination overcame all obstacles

definitions: reduced to a state of decay, collapse, or disintegration
reduced to poverty or bankruptcy; financially destroyed
examples: The ruined castle attracted many tourists
The storm left ruined homes everywhere
The ruined businessman lost everything in the crash
She was financially ruined by medical bills

definitions: causing or likely to cause complete destruction or collapse
costing far more than can be afforded; financially disastrous
examples: The ruinous war devastated both countries
Years of neglect had ruinous effects
The ruinous cost of healthcare bankrupted them
They faced ruinous legal fees

definitions: marked with straight parallel lines for writing
controlled or governed by a particular person, group, or principle
examples: She wrote neatly on ruled paper
The ruled notebook helped maintain straight lines
The ruled territory remained under occupation
Their ruled existence allowed no freedom

definitions: having political power or authority to govern
most powerful, important, or prevalent
examples: The ruling party faced strong opposition
The ruling class controlled all resources
Her ruling passion was music
Cost was the ruling factor in their decision

definitions: peculiar, strange, or odd in an unusual way (British informal)
examples: That's a rum way to behave at dinner
He told some rum stories about his travels
What a rum coincidence meeting you here
She had rum ideas about education

definitions: making a deep, continuous rolling sound like distant thunder
examples: The rumbling thunder announced the approaching storm
His rumbling voice commanded attention
We heard rumbling sounds from the volcano
The rumbling train shook the platform

definitions: showing signs of excessive alcohol consumption; appearing drunk (informal)
examples: His rummy breath revealed his drinking problem
The old man had a rummy appearance
She noticed his rummy eyes at the meeting
The rummy smell gave him away

definitions: having escaped from control, captivity, or a place of confinement
happening very easily or quickly and overwhelmingly
examples: The runaway train couldn't be stopped
Police searched for the runaway teenager
The book became a runaway bestseller
It was a runaway victory for the home team

definitions: relating to or written in ancient Germanic alphabetic characters
examples: The runic inscriptions dated from the Viking age
She studied runic symbols and their meanings
The ancient stone bore runic markings
He translated the runic text carefully

definitions: flowing continuously, especially of water
currently operating or functioning
done or happening consecutively without interruption
examples: The cabin had running water and electricity
She left the tap running all night
Keep the engine running while I check something
Is your refrigerator running properly?
This is his third running year as champion
She worked five running days without rest

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the countryside rather than the town
examples: They moved to a rural area for peace and quiet
Rural communities often lack public transport
The rural economy depends heavily on agriculture
She preferred rural life to city living

definitions: done or completed too quickly and without proper care
examples: The rush job showed many errors
They made a rush decision they later regretted
Don't make rush judgments about people
The rush repair failed within days

definitions: done hastily without adequate time or preparation
feeling under pressure to hurry; having insufficient time
examples: Her rushed presentation lacked important details
The rushed meal gave everyone indigestion
I felt rushed during the entire exam
She seemed rushed and couldn't talk long

definitions: having a reddish-brown color like autumn leaves
examples: The russet apples were perfect for pie
Her russet hair gleamed in sunlight
The trees turned russet in October
He wore a russet leather jacket

definitions: having the reddish-brown color of iron oxide
examples: She painted the fence a rust color
The rust fabric matched the autumn decor
His rust sweater complemented his coloring
The car was a distinctive rust shade

definitions: affected by rust; corroded through oxidation of iron
examples: The rusted gate squeaked when opened
They replaced all the rusted pipes
His rusted tools were beyond repair
The rusted chain finally broke

definitions: having the characteristics of country life; simple and unsophisticated
made in a plain and simple fashion, typical of the countryside
examples: The rustic charm of the cottage appealed to visitors
They enjoyed the rustic lifestyle
The rustic furniture was handmade from logs
She decorated with rustic wooden signs

definitions: making a soft crackling sound like dry leaves or paper
examples: The rustling leaves announced the wind's arrival
She heard rustling sounds in the bushes
The rustling papers distracted everyone
A rustling noise came from the attic

definitions: affected by rust; covered with reddish-brown oxidation
impaired through lack of recent practice or use
examples: The rusty nails were dangerous to handle
She drove an old rusty car
My French is pretty rusty after years abroad
His rusty skills needed refreshing

definitions: having or showing no pity or compassion for others
examples: The ruthless dictator eliminated all opposition
Her ruthless ambition destroyed friendships
They faced ruthless competition in the market
His ruthless efficiency impressed the board

definitions: relating to a period of paid leave for study or travel
examples: She took a sabbatical year to write her book
His sabbatical leave started in September
The professor's sabbatical research proved groundbreaking
They planned sabbatical activities carefully

definitions: having a black or very dark brown color
examples: Her sable hair contrasted with fair skin
The artist used sable tones for shadows
He wore a sable coat to the opera
The sable sky threatened rain

definitions: excessively sweet or sentimental in a way that seems false
examples: Her saccharine smile didn't fool anyone
The movie's saccharine ending disappointed critics
His saccharine compliments seemed insincere
The saccharine love song made them cringe

definitions: having been dismissed from a job, typically for poor performance
examples: The sacked employee cleared his desk quietly
All sacked workers received severance pay
She felt humiliated after being sacked
The sacked manager sued for wrongful dismissal

definitions: relating to or constituting a religious sacrament or sacred symbolic act
examples: The sacramental wine was blessed before communion
They performed the sacramental rites solemnly
The sacramental objects were kept in a special place
Her sacramental duties required daily prayer

definitions: connected with God or dedicated to a religious purpose and deserving veneration
regarded with great respect and reverence; too valuable to be interfered with
examples: The sacred texts were handled with reverence
They entered the sacred temple quietly
Their weekly dinner was sacred family time
She held her privacy as sacred

definitions: relating to or constituting a sacrifice offered to a deity or for a religious purpose
examples: The sacrificial altar was centuries old
They performed sacrificial rituals at dawn
His sacrificial gesture saved the company
She made a sacrificial decision for her children

definitions: feeling or showing sorrow; unhappy or sorrowful
causing sorrow or regret; unfortunate or regrettable
pathetically inadequate or unfashionable; deplorable
examples: She felt sad after hearing the news
His sad expression revealed his grief
It's sad that they never reconciled
The sad truth finally emerged
That's a pretty sad excuse for dinner
His sad attempts at humor fell flat
